title: Cutting — Cutting on Shapes (Circle and Square)
description: The child cuts along the outlines of a circle and square drawn on paper. This builds on straight-line and curve cutting, progressing to cutting out complete shapes.
instructions:
1. Draw or print a large circle (4-inch diameter) and a large square on separate papers.
2. Review proper scissor grip and the technique of turning the paper.
3. Demonstrate cutting along the circle outline: turn the paper smoothly while cutting.
4. Demonstrate cutting along the square: cut one side, rotate, cut the next side.
5. Let the child cut both shapes.
6. Glue the cut shapes onto a contrasting background paper.

slides.heading: Cutting Shapes
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun lesson we're going to do! We're going to learn how to cut out some special shapes, like a circle and a square. It's like being a super artist!

slides.setup_instructions: Draw thick outlines of a circle (4 inches) and square (4 inches) on separate papers.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all the things we need for our cutting adventure! We have some scissors for cutting, and paper with a circle and a square on it. We also have glue to stick our shapes down, and another piece of paper for our picture. Ask your grown-up to help you find all these treasures!

slides.text: 'Today we're going to cut out SHAPES! First, the circle. Remember: turn the paper, not the scissors.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's start with the circle! Remember how we learned to hold our scissors? We're going to go around the circle line, and when we cut, we'll turn the paper a little bit to help the scissors make a nice curve.

slides.text: Demonstrate cutting the circle slowly, feeding the paper with the non-cutting hand.
slides.mascot_explanation: Watch me! See how I go slowly around the circle? I use my other hand to help turn the paper just right. This helps the scissors cut smoothly all the way around.

slides.text: 'Now the square. Cut along one side, stop at the corner, turn the paper, cut the next side.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for the square! We cut along one straight line, then we stop at the corner and turn the paper to cut the next straight line. We do this for all four sides of the square.

slides.text: Child cuts both shapes. 'It doesn't have to be perfect — you're learning!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the super cutter! You get to cut out your circle and your square. Don't worry if it's not perfectly straight, we're practicing and learning, and you're doing a great job!

slides.prompt: Cut out your circle and square. Glue them onto the background paper to make a picture. What could they become?
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to make a picture with our shapes! Let's take our circle and our square that we cut out and glue them onto the other paper. What do you think they could become? Maybe a sun and a window?

slides.text: Display the shape art. 'You can cut circles AND squares now!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child cut out a recognizable circle and square shape?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay! Look at your amazing art! You did it! You learned how to cut out a circle and a square all by yourself! That's so super cool!

parent_notes: Cutting out complete shapes is a significant milestone. Circles require continuous turning of the paper — a complex bilateral coordination task. Squares require stopping at corners and changing direction. Don't expect perfection; wobbly shapes are normal and will improve with practice. These cut shapes can be the start of shape collages, robots, animals, and other art projects.

title: Sandpaper Letters — o (short vowel) and Review
description: Introduction to sandpaper letter 'o' (short vowel as in 'octopus'). The child now knows three vowels and can build an even wider variety of CVC words.
instructions:
1. Present sandpaper letter 'o' (blue background for vowel).
2. Trace while saying /o/ (short o, as in 'octopus'). Repeat 3 times.
3. Three-period lesson.
4. Review all 9 letters.
5. Build new words with /o/: top, mop, pot, cot, rot, cop.
6. Compare words: cat/cot, tip/top, pit/pot — changing the vowel changes the word!

slides.heading: Sandpaper Letter
slides.mascot_explanation: Hello friend! Look at this special slide. It's about a new letter we're going to learn today, and it's a very special kind of letter called a vowel. We're going to have so much fun learning it together!

slides.setup_instructions: Place 'o' on tray. Blue background — third vowel!
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these things! We have a bumpy letter 'o' that feels so neat, and our other letters from before. We also have little letters to build words and some fun toys that start with our new sound. Can you ask a grown-up to help you find these special things for our game?

slides.text: 'Another vowel! This one says /o/ — like the beginning of octopus.' Trace the circular shape. Say /o/.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is our new letter, 'o'! It feels like a little circle, doesn't it? When we say its name, it sounds like the beginning of "octopus." Let's trace it with our finger and say /o/ together, just like this!

slides.text: Child traces. Three-period lesson. Then review all 9 letters.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to feel the letter 'o' and trace it with your finger while we say its sound. After we practice our new letter, we'll play a game and trace all the letters we know so far to make sure we remember them all!

slides.text: New words: /t/-/o/-/p/ = top! /m/-/o/-/p/ = mop! /p/-/o/-/t/ = pot!
slides.mascot_explanation: We're going to make some super fun words now! We can put the sounds together like this: /t/-/o/-/p/ makes "top"! Then we can make "mop" and "pot" too. It's like building with our letter sounds!

slides.text: Vowel swap: build 'cat' then change to 'cot.' Build 'tip' then change to 'top.' 'The vowel makes ALL the difference!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Isn't it amazing how a little vowel sound can change a whole word? We can make "cat," but if we change the vowel sound, it becomes "cot"! We're going to play a game where we swap the vowels to make new words.

slides.prompt: Build 5 words with /o/: top, mop, pot, cot, rot. Then try the vowel swap challenge with 3 word pairs!
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to play! Let's build some words with our new letter 'o', like "top" and "mop." Then, we'll do a super fun challenge and change the vowel sound in words to make new ones, just like we learned! You can do it!

slides.text: 'Three vowels now! a, i, o. Every word needs at least one vowel — they're the heart of every word.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify /o/ and build CVC words using all three vowels?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay! You learned a brand new vowel sound, /o/, and you practiced making so many words! You now know three special vowels, and they are like the heart of every word. You did such a great job building words today!

parent_notes: With three vowels (a, i, o) and six consonants (s, m, t, p, c, r), the child can now build dozens of real CVC words. The vowel swap exercise is powerful because it shows the child that vowels determine how a word sounds. Short /o/ is usually easy for children because it's a distinct, rounded sound. Keep building words daily — it's the most impactful language activity.

title: Cards and Counters — Practice and Odd/Even Games
description: Continued practice with cards and counters, deepening the understanding of odd and even numbers through games and daily life connections.
instructions:
1. Set up cards and counters independently.
2. Review: 'Which numbers are odd? Which are even?'
3. Odd/even game: call out a number, child says 'odd!' or 'even!'
4. Real-life connection: 'Can 3 people share 6 cookies equally?' (Even = yes!) 'Can 3 people share 7?' (Odd = one left over!)
5. Sort numeral cards into odd and even piles.
6. Extension: predict — is 12 odd or even? 15? 20?

slides.heading: Odd and Even
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! Today we're going to play some super fun games with numbers. We'll learn about numbers that are "odd" and numbers that are "even," like a special secret code!

slides.setup_instructions: Let the child set up cards and counters independently.
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, we get to use our special number cards and these cool little counters. The number cards have numbers on them, and the counters are like little friends that help us count. Let's get them all ready for our games!

slides.text: 'Set up your cards and counters all by yourself today!' Observe and assist only if needed.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the boss of the numbers and counters! Can you put all the number cards and all the little counters out by yourself? You're so good at getting things ready!

slides.text: Point to numbers: 'Is 7 odd or even?' 'How can you tell?' (The bottom counter has no partner.)
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's look at our numbers. See number 7? We can use our counters to see if it's odd or even. If there's one counter all by itself with no friend, it's an odd number!

slides.text: Real-life: 'If we have 4 cookies and 2 people, can we share evenly? 4 is EVEN — yes! What about 5 cookies?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Imagine we have yummy cookies! If we have 4 cookies and share them with 2 friends, everyone gets the same amount – that's like an even number! But if we have 5 cookies, someone might not get the same amount.

slides.text: Flash game: hold up a number, child says odd or even as fast as they can.
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready, set, go! I'm going to show you a number super fast, and you tell me if it's odd or even. Try to be a number whiz!

slides.prompt: Sort all the number cards into two piles: odd and even. Then predict: is 11 odd or even? Test it with counters!
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's play a sorting game! We'll put all the number cards into two groups: one for odd numbers and one for even numbers. Then we can guess if a new number is odd or even and check with our counters!

slides.text: 'Odd, even, odd, even — it's a pattern that goes on forever!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child quickly identify numbers 1-10 as odd or even?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job learning about odd and even numbers today! You are so smart at seeing which numbers have partners and which ones are all by themselves. You're a math superstar!

parent_notes: The connection to sharing ('Can we share fairly?') makes odd and even meaningful to children. Even numbers can be shared equally between two people; odd numbers always have one left over. Extending to numbers beyond 10 helps the child see the pattern: even numbers always end in 0, 2, 4, 6, or 8. Don't teach this rule yet — let them discover it.

title: Continent Study — North America
description: Beginning an in-depth study of the continent where the child lives: North America. Learning about the countries, animals, and landmarks of the continent.
instructions:
1. Find North America on the globe (orange).
2. Show on a flat map: North America includes the United States, Canada, and Mexico.
3. Discuss: 'We live here! What do you know about where we live?'
4. Show pictures of North American animals: bald eagle, grizzly bear, moose, bison.
5. Show pictures of landmarks: Grand Canyon, Statue of Liberty, Niagara Falls.
6. Add a North America page to the Continent Book.
materials_needed: Pictures of North American animals and landmarks

slides.heading: Continent Study
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! We're going to learn all about a special place called North America. That's where we live, right here on our big planet! It's going to be so much fun exploring it together.

slides.setup_instructions: Gather pictures beforehand. Have the globe and map available.
slides.mascot_explanation: To learn about North America, we need some special things! We have a big round globe that shows all the places on Earth, a flat map to see the countries, and some cool pictures of animals and buildings. We also have a special book where we'll put our work. Can you help me find all these things?

slides.text: Find North America on the globe. 'This is our home continent! It's the ORANGE one. It's the third largest continent.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's find our home on this big globe! See this orange part? That's North America! It's like a big land hug for our country. It's the third biggest place on the whole Earth!

slides.text: Show the map: 'Canada is to the north, the United States is in the middle, and Mexico is to the south.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now let's look at this flat map. See how North America is like a puzzle? Up top is Canada, where it can be very snowy. In the middle, where we live, is the United States. And down at the bottom is Mexico, with warm sunshine!

slides.text: Show animal pictures: 'These animals live in North America. A bald eagle, a grizzly bear, a moose, a bison.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at these amazing animals! This is a bald eagle, with big wings that fly high up. This is a big grizzly bear, like the ones we might see in stories. And this is a moose with giant antlers, and a bison with fuzzy fur! They all live here in North America!

slides.prompt: Add a North America page to your Continent Book. Color it orange. Draw one animal and one landmark. Write 'North America.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to make our own page for our Continent Book! We'll color it orange, just like North America on the globe. Then, pick your favorite animal and a cool building from North America to draw. Don't forget to write "North America" so we remember our special place!

slides.text: 'North America is a wonderful continent full of amazing animals and places!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child locate North America and name at least 2 countries within it?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You learned so much about North America today! You helped me find it on the globe and name some of the countries. It's so cool that we live on such an amazing continent with wild animals and awesome places!

parent_notes: Starting continent studies with the child's home continent makes the learning personal and meaningful. Use photos, books, or videos to bring the animals and landmarks to life. If you've visited any places in North America, share those stories. The continent study will continue over several weeks, one continent at a time, building a rich understanding of the world.

title: Read-Aloud: Corduroy
description: Reading Don Freeman's story about a stuffed bear who wants a home and a friend. Exploring themes of friendship, acceptance, and belonging.
instructions:
1. Show the cover. 'This is Corduroy. He's a teddy bear in a department store.'
2. Read the story with warmth and expression.
3. Pause at key moments: 'Why do you think the mother didn't buy Corduroy?'
4. Discuss: 'How did Corduroy feel when Lisa took him home?'
5. Talk about what makes a good friend.
6. Extension: bring a stuffed animal and tell its 'story.'
materials_needed: Optional: a stuffed bear for retelling

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! This is the book we're going to read today. It's called Corduroy, and it's about a sweet teddy bear. We're going to have so much fun with this story!

slides.setup_instructions: Sit comfortably together.
slides.mascot_explanation: To get ready for our story, we need a few special things. First, we need the Corduroy book so we can see the pictures. If you have a favorite stuffed animal, you can bring them too, so they can listen to the story with us!

slides.text: Cover: 'This is Corduroy. He lives in a big department store. He's waiting for someone to take him home.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at the cover! This is Corduroy, a teddy bear who lives in a big store. He's just waiting and hoping someone will pick him to be their special friend.

slides.text: Read slowly. Let the child study the illustrations of the store at night.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to read the story, and I want you to look really closely at the pictures. See how the store looks at night? It's like a secret adventure just for us to see.

slides.text: Discuss: 'Corduroy went on an adventure at night! What was he looking for?' (His missing button.)
slides.mascot_explanation: Corduroy went on a little adventure all by himself! He was looking for something very important that he lost. Can you guess what it was? It was his button!

slides.prompt: After reading: 'Have you ever waited for something you really wanted? How did it feel? What makes Corduroy and Lisa good friends?'
slides.mascot_explanation: After we finish reading, we'll talk about how Corduroy felt when he was waiting, and how Lisa became his friend. We can also think about what makes someone a good friend, just like Corduroy and Lisa.

slides.text: 'Lisa loved Corduroy just the way he was — even without his button. That's what real friends do.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child retell the main events and discuss the friendship theme?
slides.mascot_explanation: Isn't it wonderful that Lisa loved Corduroy even with his missing button? That means she's a super good friend! It shows us that friends love each other just the way they are.

parent_notes: Corduroy teaches that love and friendship aren't about perfection — Lisa loved Corduroy even with a missing button. This is a wonderful book for discussing feelings: loneliness, hope, belonging, and joy. The nighttime department store adventure captivates children. If your child has a special stuffed animal, connect: 'Your bear is special just like Corduroy!'

title: Color Tablets — Box 2 Introduction
description: Introduction to Color Tablets Box 2, containing 11 pairs of colors (22 tablets). The child matches all pairs, discriminating between similar shades.
instructions:
1. Open Color Box 2. Spread all 22 tablets on the mat.
2. Pick up one tablet. 'I need to find the one that matches exactly.'
3. Compare by placing tablets side by side.
4. Find and pair all 11 colors: red, blue, yellow, orange, green, purple, pink, brown, gray, black, white.
5. Name each color using the three-period lesson as needed.
6. Arrange the matched pairs in a row.

slides.heading: Color Tablets
slides.mascot_explanation: Look, this is our special Color Box 2! It has lots and lots of colors for us to learn and play with today. We're going to become super color detectives!

slides.setup_instructions: Place the box on a neutral-colored mat. Handle tablets by the edges.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these pretty color squares inside this box! These are called color tablets, and we need them to play a matching game. Can you ask a grown-up to help you get the box and put them on this nice, plain mat?

slides.text: 'Box 2 has MANY more colors! Let's spread them all out and find the matching pairs.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's open up our box of colors and take all the little color squares out. We're going to spread them all around on the mat so we can see them better. We need to find the colors that are exactly the same!

slides.text: Pick up a tablet. 'This looks orange. Let me find the other orange.' Compare side by side.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, pick up one color square. Look at its color very closely! See this one? It looks like a yummy orange. Now, we need to find its twin, the *exact* same orange color, hiding somewhere else on the mat.

slides.text: Some colors look similar (brown and orange, pink and red). 'Look carefully — are they the SAME or just similar?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Sometimes, two colors might look a little bit alike, like maybe a light red and a dark pink. We have to look super, super close to see if they are the *exact* same color or just friends that look similar.

slides.text: After matching all 11 pairs, name each color. Three-period lesson for any new color names.
slides.mascot_explanation: We found all the matching pairs! Yay us! Now, let's say the name of each color together. If there's a color you don't know, I can help you learn its name, just like we learned "red" and "blue."

slides.prompt: Mix all 22 tablets and match them again! This time, can you do it faster? Name each color as you match.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's mix all the color squares up again! Can you find all the matching pairs super fast this time? Say the color's name when you find its match. You're doing such a great job!

slides.text: 'Eleven colors! Your eyes can tell the difference between very similar colors now.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child match all 11 pairs and name at least 8 colors?
slides.mascot_explanation: You matched all eleven colors, and you're so good at telling them apart! You can see when colors are just a little bit different, like magic! You are a super color expert now!

parent_notes: Box 2 is a significant step up from Box 1 (which had only 3 pairs). The 11 pairs include some that are easy to confuse (brown/orange, pink/red, gray/white). Handle tablets by the wooden edges to keep the color surfaces clean. If your child doesn't have official color tablets, you can make pairs from paint chips at a hardware store.

title: Word Building — Three-Letter Phonetic Reading
description: The child begins reading CVC words independently. Moving from building words to READING pre-made words — a critical transition.
instructions:
1. Build a word with the moveable alphabet while the child watches: 'c-a-t.'
2. 'Can you read this word? Sound it out: /c/...../a/...../t/... cat!'
3. Build 5 more words. Child reads each one.
4. Now: write words on paper strips. Child reads the strips.
5. Match word strips to objects: 'cat' strip goes next to the cat toy.
6. This is the transition from writing to reading — celebrate!
materials_needed: Paper strips with CVC words written on them

slides.heading: Reading Words!
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at that! Today we get to learn how to read words! It's like a secret code that grown-ups use, and now you're going to learn it too! We're going to be super readers!

slides.setup_instructions: Pre-write 8-10 CVC words on strips. Gather matching objects: cat, pot, mop, pin, etc.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's see what fun things we need for our reading adventure! We have these cool letter tiles, and we'll use them to make words. Then we have strips of paper with words on them, and some toys or pictures that match those words! Ask your grown-up to help you find all these things so we can get started!

slides.text: Build 'cat' with the moveable alphabet. 'Can you read this? Start at the beginning and say each sound.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Look, I made a word with our letter tiles! See the 'c' and the 'a' and the 't'? Let's say the sounds together really slowly: /c/.... /a/.... /t/. Can you hear the word we made?

slides.text: Child sounds out: '/c/...../a/...../t/... CAT!' 'You just READ a word!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay! You did it! When you put those sounds together, /c/.... /a/.... /t/, it makes the word "CAT"! You just read a word all by yourself! Give yourself a big clap!

slides.text: Build 5 more words. Let the child read each one independently. Help only if needed.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to make some more words! We're going to use the letter tiles to make new words, and then you get to be the super reader and sound them out. I know you can do it!

slides.text: Switch to paper strips: 'Now read THIS word.' The child sounds out each written word.
slides.mascot_explanation: Great job reading those words with the tiles! Now we have some words written on paper, like a secret message. Let's look at this first word and sound it out together, just like we did before. You are such a good reader!

slides.prompt: Match game: read each word strip and place it next to the matching object. Cat strip goes by the cat!
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to play a matching game! We'll read the word on the paper strip, and then we'll find the toy or picture that matches that word. So if we read "cat," we put the word strip next to the cat toy! Let's see if you can match them all!

slides.text: 'You are READING! You can look at letters and figure out the word. That is reading!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child sound out and read at least 5 CVC words independently?
slides.mascot_explanation: You are an amazing reader! You looked at the letters and sounds and figured out the words all by yourself! That is super reading, and I am so proud of you! You did a fantastic job today!

parent_notes: This is a landmark lesson — the child transitions from encoding (building/writing words) to decoding (reading words someone else made). In Montessori, children typically write before they read. The matching activity proves comprehension: the child doesn't just say the word, they understand what it means. Keep the words phonetically regular — no silent letters or complex spellings yet.

title: Number Rod Combinations — Making 10 Review and Recording
description: Reviewing combinations that make 10 with number rods and recording them on paper as equations.
instructions:
1. Place rod 10 at the top of the mat.
2. Below it, place rod 9. 'What rod fills the gap to make 10?' Try rod 1. '9 and 1 make 10!'
3. Continue: 8+2, 7+3, 6+4, 5+5.
4. Record all combinations.
5. 'And 10 by itself makes 10!'
6. 'Making 10' is one of the most important number facts in all of mathematics.

slides.heading: Making 10!
slides.subheading: Number Rod Combinations — Making 10 Review and Recording
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun slide! It's all about making the number 10, like a big, happy group of ten things! We're going to learn all the special ways we can put smaller numbers together to get ten.

slides.setup_instructions: Have all rods ready. Place rod 10 at the top of the mat.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these colorful blocks! These are called number rods, and each one is a different size. We also have a big mat, like a special carpet for our blocks, and some paper to draw on. We'll use these to help us find all the ways to make ten!

slides.text: Place rod 10 at the top. 'This is our target — TEN! Let's find all the ways to make ten.'
slides.mascot_explanation: See the longest rod on top? That's our ten! It's like our goal, the big number we want to make. We're going to use the other rods to see how they fit together underneath to make this super-long rod.

slides.text: Place rod 9 below. 'What fills the gap?' Rod 1! '9 + 1 = 10!' Try 8 — need 2. '8 + 2 = 10!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's put the next longest rod, number 9, right under our ten rod. See the little space left over? That tiny little rod is number 1! So, 9 and 1 together make our big ten rod. It's like two friends holding hands to make a bigger friend!

slides.text: Continue: 7+3=10, 6+4=10, 5+5=10. 'Five and five make ten — that's a double!'
slides.mascot_explanation: We're going to keep doing that with the other rods. We'll try rod 8 and see what little rod fits perfectly next to it to make ten. Then we'll do rod 7 and rod 6, and even 5 and 5! It's like a puzzle where all the pieces have to add up to ten.

slides.text: Record all combinations on paper. Read them aloud together.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to be super-smart recorders! We're going to write down all the number pairs that made ten. We'll look at our rods and write down things like "9 + 1 = 10" on our paper. It's like keeping a special list of our number friends!

slides.prompt: Find ALL the ways to make 10 with the rods. Can you do it without help? Write them down!
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, your turn to be the super-finder! Can you take all the number rods and find all the different ways to make our big ten rod? Try to find as many as you can all by yourself, and then write them down on your paper. You can do it!

slides.text: 'Making 10 is one of the most important things in math! 9+1, 8+2, 7+3, 6+4, 5+5.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child find at least 4 rod combinations that make 10?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such an amazing job making ten today! We found so many ways, like 9 and 1, and 8 and 2, and even 5 and 5! Knowing how to make ten is like having a secret superpower in math, and you're becoming a math superhero!

parent_notes: Combinations of 10 are THE most important number facts in elementary math. They're used in mental math, regrouping, estimation, and more. Play '10 fingers': hold up some fingers, child tells how many are hidden to make 10. Make this a daily game: 'I have 3 apples, how many more to make 10?' Memorizing these combinations will serve your child for years.

title: Magnetic or Non-Magnetic — Introduction
description: The child experiments with a magnet to discover which objects are magnetic and which are not. Another classification exercise using the scientific method.
instructions:
1. Show the child a magnet. Let them feel it pull toward a metal object.
2. 'A magnet attracts some things but not others. Let's find out which!'
3. Gather 10-12 objects: paper clip, coin, wooden block, key, plastic cup, foil, nail, crayon, spoon, rubber band, rock, fabric.
4. Predict: 'Will the magnet attract this?' Test each one.
5. Sort into two groups: magnetic and non-magnetic.
6. Discuss: 'What do the magnetic objects have in common?' (They contain iron/metal.)
materials_needed: 10-12 test objects (mix of metal and non-metal)

slides.heading: Magnetic or Not?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at that! This slide has a fun question for us: "Magnetic or Not?" It means we get to be super scientists and discover what things magnets like to stick to!

slides.setup_instructions: Gather diverse objects. Include some tricky ones (aluminum foil is NOT magnetic even though it's metal!).
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our special science tools ready! We have a strong magnet that can pull things, and lots of different objects like a paper clip, a coin, and even a crayon. We also have two mats to help us sort our findings later. Can you ask a grown-up to help you find all these things so we can play?

slides.text: 'This is a MAGNET. It has a special power — it can pull some things toward it. Watch!' Demonstrate with a paper clip.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here's our amazing magnet! Feel how it pulls toward this little metal paper clip? That's its special power! Magnets have a magic pull for some things.

slides.text: 'But it doesn't pull everything. Let's test!' Hold the magnet near a wooden block. 'Nothing happens — wood is not magnetic.'
slides.mascot_explanation: But watch this! When I bring the magnet close to this wooden block, nothing happens. The magnet doesn't pull it at all. That's because wood is not magnetic, so our magnet doesn't stick to it.

slides.text: For each object: predict, test, sort. 'Do you think this coin will be magnetic?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the super scientist! For each thing we have, let's guess first: do you think the magnet will stick to it? Then we'll try it out and see!

slides.prompt: Test all the objects! Sort them into magnetic and non-magnetic groups. What do the magnetic ones have in common?
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the best part! We get to test all our things with the magnet. We'll put all the things the magnet sticks to on one mat, and the things it doesn't stick to on the other mat. It's like sorting our treasures!

slides.text: 'Magnets attract objects that contain iron! That's why some metals are magnetic but plastic and wood are not.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child predict and test whether objects are magnetic and explain the pattern?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! We learned that magnets love to stick to things that have iron in them, like some metals! That's why the magnet pulled the nail and the spoon but not the crayon or the block. You are such a great scientist!

parent_notes: This experiment follows the same scientific method as sink/float: predict, test, observe. Children are fascinated by magnets. The key discovery is that not all metals are magnetic — aluminum, copper, and gold are not. Only iron-containing metals are. Let the child explore freely with the magnet after the structured lesson. Magnets are wonderful for independent investigation.

title: Clay Work — Pinch Pot
description: The child learns to make a simple pinch pot from clay. This develops hand strength, fine motor skills, and three-dimensional creativity.
instructions:
1. Provide a ball of clay (air-dry clay or modeling clay).
2. Demonstrate: roll into a smooth ball between palms.
3. Push thumb into the center of the ball to make a hollow.
4. Pinch and turn, pinch and turn — expanding the walls.
5. Even out the rim. Smooth the outside.
6. Let the pinch pot dry. Decorate later with paint.
materials_needed: Small bowl of water for smoothing

slides.heading: Clay Work
slides.mascot_explanation: Look! Today we're going to make something super cool with clay! We're going to learn how to make a special little pot called a pinch pot. It’s going to be so much fun!

slides.setup_instructions: Knead the clay until pliable. Work on a mat or board to protect the table.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all the things we need for our clay adventure! We have a soft ball of clay that feels like Play-Doh, a mat to keep our table clean, and a little bowl of water. We might even use some special little tools to help shape our clay! Go find these things with a grown-up so we can start playing.

slides.text: 'Today we make something from clay! First, roll it into a smooth ball.' Demonstrate rolling between palms.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, first things first! Let's take our ball of clay and warm it up. We're going to roll it between our hands, like we're making a yummy cookie. Keep rolling until it's nice and smooth all around.

slides.text: 'Now push your thumb into the center — not all the way through! Make a little cave.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for the magic part! Gently poke your thumb right into the middle of your clay ball. We're making a little hole, like a tiny cave inside, but be careful not to go all the way through to the other side.

slides.text: 'Pinch the walls between your thumb and fingers. Turn a little. Pinch again. Turn. Pinch. Turn.'
slides.mascot_explanation: See these walls we're making? We're going to pinch the clay walls between our thumb and our fingers. Pinch a little bit, then turn the clay just a little bit, and pinch again. We keep doing this all around the clay.

slides.text: 'Keep pinching and turning until the walls are even and the pot opens up. Smooth with wet fingers.'
slides.mascot_explanation: We're almost done with our pot! Keep pinching and turning, pinching and turning, until the walls are all the same thickness. Then, we can use our wet fingers to make the top edge nice and smooth. Look, it's starting to look like a real pot!

slides.prompt: Make your own pinch pot! Can you make the walls even? Try making the rim smooth. What will you keep in your pot?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, it's time to make your very own pinch pot! Can you make the sides all even and the top edge super smooth? Think about what cool things you might want to keep inside your special pot later. You can do it!

slides.text: Set the pot on a shelf to dry. 'You made a real pot from a ball of clay! People have made pots this way for thousands of years.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child create a basic pinch pot with recognizable walls and opening?
slides.mascot_explanation: We did it! You made a real pot all by yourself from a little ball of clay! We just need to put it somewhere safe so it can dry and get hard. People have been making pots like this for a very, very long time, just like you!

parent_notes: Pinch pots are one of humanity's oldest art forms. The repetitive pinch-and-turn motion builds hand strength and coordination. Air-dry clay is best for home use — no kiln needed. If the clay cracks, wet fingers smooth it out. Once dry, pinch pots can be painted with tempera or acrylic. This connects to cultural studies: many ancient civilizations made pinch pots.

title: Sewing — Introduction to Threading a Needle
description: The child learns to thread a large blunt needle with yarn. This is the foundation for all sewing work and develops fine motor control and patience.
instructions:
1. Present a large plastic or blunt metal needle and thick yarn.
2. Demonstrate: lick or tape the end of the yarn to stiffen it.
3. Hold the needle in one hand, the yarn in the other.
4. Poke the yarn through the eye of the needle.
5. Pull through and tie a knot at the end.
6. Let the child practice threading several times.

slides.heading: Sewing
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! We're going to learn about sewing today, and that means we get to do something super special called threading a needle. It's like giving our yarn a tiny little path to follow!

slides.setup_instructions: Cut yarn to about 18 inches. Wrap a small piece of tape around one end to stiffen it.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's see what fun things we need for our sewing adventure! We have a big, safe needle with a hole, and some colorful yarn to play with. We also have some tape to help our yarn be strong, and a tray to keep everything neat. Ask your grown-up to help you find these special tools!

slides.text: 'Before we can sew, we need to learn to THREAD a needle. That means putting the yarn through the tiny hole.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Before we can sew cool things, we need to do something important first! We need to learn how to put the yarn through the little hole in the needle. It's like threading a tiny tunnel!

slides.text: Show the eye of the needle. 'This hole is called the EYE. We push the yarn through it.'
slides.mascot_explanation: See this little hole on the needle? It's called the "eye," just like you have eyes to see with! We need to push the yarn right through this tiny eye so we can start sewing.

slides.text: Demonstrate: hold needle still, push stiffened yarn end through the eye. 'Got it! Now pull it through.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, watch me! I'm holding the needle still, and I'm gently pushing the end of the yarn into the eye. Once it goes through, I'll pull the yarn all the way through to the other side. See? It's like magic!

slides.text: Tie a knot at the other end. 'The knot keeps the yarn from pulling all the way through.'
slides.mascot_explanation: After we pull the yarn through the needle, we need to tie a knot at the very end. This knot is like a little stopper so our yarn doesn't slip out of the needle when we're sewing. It keeps everything in place!

slides.prompt: Practice threading the needle 5 times. Pull the yarn out and try again each time. It gets easier with practice!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to try! We're going to practice putting the yarn through the needle's eye. Try it a few times, and don't worry if it's tricky at first. We can pull it out and try again, and it will get easier and easier!

slides.text: 'Threading a needle takes patience and steady hands. You did it!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child thread the needle independently at least once?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, you did it! Threading a needle takes a little bit of patience and a steady hand, and you were so good at it. You learned how to put the yarn through the needle all by yourself!

parent_notes: Threading a needle is genuinely difficult for young children and requires concentration, fine motor control, and patience. Use the largest needle and thickest yarn you can find for beginners. Taping or stiffening the yarn end is crucial — floppy yarn is nearly impossible to thread. This is a life skill as well as a Montessori exercise. Some children will find this frustrating; keep sessions short and praise effort.

title: Phonetic Reading — Object and Word Matching
description: The child reads CVC word cards and matches them to corresponding objects. Building reading comprehension through hands-on matching.
instructions:
1. Set out 8-10 small objects on a mat.
2. Place word cards face down in a pile.
3. Child turns over a card, sounds it out, reads the word.
4. Finds the matching object and places the card next to it.
5. Continue until all cards are matched.
6. Check together: 'Does pot match the pot? Yes!'
materials_needed: 8-10 small objects (cat, pot, cup, mat, pin, top, mop, rat, cap, rug)

slides.heading: Reading and Matching
slides.mascot_explanation: Look! This is the name of our fun game today. We are going to be super readers and match words to pictures, just like detectives!

slides.setup_instructions: Write one word per card in clear lowercase letters. Arrange objects on the mat with space between them.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all the cool things we need! We have some toys and other things here, and then we have these special cards with words on them. Can you ask a grown-up to help you get all these things ready on a mat?

slides.text: 'Here are some objects you know. And here are word cards. Can you read each card and find the matching object?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, friend, we have our toys and our word cards! Your job is to look at one word card, read it, and then find the toy that matches the word. You can do it!

slides.text: Turn over the first card. 'Sound it out: /m/...../o/...../p/... MOP! Where is the mop?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's turn over the first card! Hear the sounds? /m/ ... /o/ ... /p/. When we put them together, it says "MOP"! Now, can you find the mop toy from our pile?

slides.text: Place the card next to the object. Continue with each card.
slides.mascot_explanation: Great job finding the mop! Now, put the word card right next to the mop toy so everyone can see they match. We're going to do this for all the cards!

slides.prompt: Match all the word cards to their objects. Read each word aloud as you place it. Can you get them all right?
slides.mascot_explanation: You are doing so wonderfully reading all the words and finding the right toys! Keep going, match all the word cards to their toys. You are such a good reader!

slides.text: 'You READ every word and matched it! That proves you understood what you read. You are a reader!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child read and correctly match at least 6 out of 8 word cards?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You read every single word and matched it to the right toy! That shows you are a super reader and you understand what the words mean. Yay, you!

parent_notes: Object-to-word matching proves that the child is not just decoding (making sounds) but comprehending (understanding meaning). This is a crucial distinction. If the child can sound out 'mop' but doesn't connect it to the mop object, they need more work on blending sounds into words. Keep all words phonetically regular at this stage — no sight words or tricky spellings yet.

title: Numeral Writing on Paper — 1 through 5
description: Transitioning from sand tray to paper. The child writes numerals 1-5 on lined paper for the first time, using proper formation learned through sandpaper numerals.
instructions:
1. Review sandpaper numerals 1-5: trace each one.
2. Write each numeral in the sand tray first.
3. Present lined paper and pencil.
4. Demonstrate writing 1: straight line down.
5. Child writes a row of 1s. Then 2s. Continue through 5.
6. Circle their best one on each row.

slides.heading: Numeral Writing
slides.mascot_explanation: Look, we're going to learn how to write numbers! We'll start with numbers 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5. It's like drawing pictures, but with numbers!

slides.setup_instructions: Have sandpaper numerals and sand tray for warm-up. Then switch to paper and pencil.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all the fun things we need for our writing adventure! We have special bumpy numbers called sandpaper numbers, a tray with sand for practicing, paper that looks like a special road, and a pencil to draw with. Can you ask your grown-up to help you find them all?

slides.text: Warm up: trace each sandpaper numeral. Then write each in the sand tray.
slides.mascot_explanation: First, we'll warm up our hands by feeling those bumpy sandpaper numbers with your finger. Then, we'll use our finger to draw the numbers in the soft sand. It's like practicing in a secret sandbox before we write them for real!

slides.text: 'Now let's try on PAPER! Paper is special because your writing stays.' Show how to hold the pencil.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, it's time for something super exciting – we get to write numbers on paper! Paper is special because when we write on it, our numbers stay there forever, just like a drawing. Let's learn how to hold our pencil just right, like a little hug.

slides.text: Demonstrate writing 1: start at the top line, straight line down to the bottom line. 'Now you try.'
slides.mascot_explanation: We're going to learn how to make the number 1! Watch me, we start at the tippy-top and draw a straight line all the way down, like a tall tree. Now it's your turn to make a tall tree for the number 1!

slides.text: Continue with 2, 3, 4, 5. Each number gets one row. 'Take your time. Big, clear numbers.'
slides.mascot_explanation: We'll keep going and learn how to make numbers 2, 3, 4, and 5, too! Each number will have its own special line on the paper road. Just take your time and make your numbers big and clear, like friendly giants.

slides.prompt: Write a row of each numeral: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5. Circle your BEST one in each row!
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to make your own rows of numbers! You'll write a line of 1s, then a line of 2s, and so on, all the way to 5. After you make each row, pick your very favorite one and circle it with your pencil – that's your super-duper best number!

slides.text: 'You're writing real numbers on real paper! Soon we'll do 6 through 10.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child write recognizable numerals 1-5 on lined paper?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay! You did it! You wrote numbers 1 through 5 all by yourself on paper, and they look amazing! You're such a super number writer, and soon we'll learn even more numbers!

parent_notes: The progression is sandpaper tracing → sand tray writing → paper writing. Each step reduces support. Don't expect perfect formation on paper yet — the muscles are still developing. Wide-ruled paper is important; regular-lined paper is too small. Let the child self-assess by circling their best attempt — this builds metacognition (thinking about their own work).

title: Grace and Courtesy — Saying Please and Thank You
description: Practicing polite words in context through role-play. The child learns when and how to say please, thank you, and you're welcome naturally.
instructions:
1. Discuss: 'What are magic words that make people feel good?'
2. Role-play asking for something: 'May I please have the scissors?'
3. Role-play receiving something: 'Thank you!' Response: 'You're welcome!'
4. Practice different scenarios: at the table, at a store, with a friend.
5. Role-play: what happens WITHOUT magic words? 'Give me that!' How does it feel?
6. Make a 'Please and Thank You' pledge together.
materials_needed: Optional: small items to pass back and forth for practice

slides.heading: Grace and Courtesy
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this! We're going to learn about being super polite and kind with our words. These special words are like magic spells that make people feel happy. We're going to learn how to use them!

items: Small items to pass back and forth
slides.setup_instructions: Gather a few objects to practice giving and receiving.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we need some things for our game! See these little toys and things? We'll use these to practice giving and getting, just like we do in real life. Can you ask your grown-up to help you find a few fun things to share?

slides.text: 'There are special words that make everyone feel happy and respected. They're called POLITE words.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Some words are like sunshine, and they make everyone feel good! We call them "polite words." They are very special words that show we care about others. Let's learn what they are!

slides.text: Model: 'May I PLEASE have the crayon?' Take it. 'THANK YOU!' Response: 'You're WELCOME!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Watch me! When I want something, I can say, "May I PLEASE have the toy?" And when you give it to me, I'll say, "THANK YOU!" Then you can say, "You're WELCOME!" It's like a happy game of words.

slides.text: Practice: pass items back and forth using please and thank you every time.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to play! Let's practice passing these toys back and forth. Remember to say "please" when you want something, and "thank you" when you get it. We'll do it together every time!

slides.text: Contrast: 'Give me that!' How does that feel? 'May I please have that?' How does THAT feel?
slides.mascot_explanation: Hmm, what if I just say "Give me that!"? Ooh, that doesn't feel very nice, does it? But when I say, "May I PLEASE have it?" and you give it to me, and I say "THANK YOU!" — that feels much better, right?

slides.prompt: Role-play: ordering food at a restaurant, borrowing a toy from a friend, receiving a gift. Use please and thank you each time!
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's pretend! We can pretend we're at a restaurant and I'm ordering yummy food, or maybe you're sharing a toy with a friend. Every time we ask for something or get something, we'll use our special polite words!

slides.text: 'Please and thank you cost nothing but they make everyone feel valued.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child use please, thank you, and you're welcome in appropriate contexts?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay! We did it! You were so good at using "please" and "thank you"! Remember how good it felt when we used those happy words? You made everyone feel so valued today!

parent_notes: Grace and courtesy lessons work best when they're reinforced all day long, not just during the lesson. Model these words yourself — children learn more from what they see than what they're told. Don't force a child to say thank you in the moment (that can create anxiety); instead, model it and practice through play. Over time, it becomes natural.

title: Nursery Rhymes — One Two Buckle My Shoe & Jack Be Nimble
description: Learning two counting/action nursery rhymes. These combine numerical sequence with rhyme and movement.
instructions:
1. Teach 'One Two Buckle My Shoe' slowly, with actions for each pair.
2. 'One, two — buckle my shoe!' (pretend to buckle) 'Three, four — shut the door!' (push shut)
3. Continue through 'nine, ten — a big fat hen!'
4. Teach 'Jack Be Nimble' — set up a small 'candlestick' (rolled paper) to jump over.
5. Recite and jump! Vary: jump high, jump low, jump slowly, jump quickly.
6. Review all 10 nursery rhymes learned so far.
materials_needed: Small object to jump over (rolled paper 'candlestick')

slides.heading: Nursery Rhymes
slides.subheading: One Two Buckle My Shoe & Jack Be Nimble
slides.mascot_explanation: Hello friend! Today we're going to have so much fun with some special songs called nursery rhymes. We'll learn two new ones: "One Two Buckle My Shoe" and "Jack Be Nimble." Get ready for some singing and moving!

slides.setup_instructions: Clear space for jumping. Make a 'candlestick' from a rolled piece of paper.
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at these fun things we might need! We have a book with our rhymes, and this cool paper tube is like a little candlestick we can jump over. If you have these things with a grown-up, it will make our rhymes even more exciting!

slides.text: Teach 'One Two Buckle My Shoe' with actions: buckle shoe, shut door, pick up sticks, lay them straight, big fat hen!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now let's learn our first rhyme, "One Two Buckle My Shoe!" We’ll pretend to buckle our shoes, shut a door, and do other fun things with our hands as we sing. It’s like a little game that helps us remember words and actions!

slides.text: Repeat together. Count along — this rhyme practices counting to 10!
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's sing that song together again! As we sing, we can count our numbers up to ten. Counting is like a superpower, and this song helps us practice it while we have fun!

slides.text: 'Jack be nimble, Jack be quick, Jack jump over the candlestick!' Jump over the paper tube!
slides.mascot_explanation: Get ready to jump! We're going to sing about Jack who is nimble and quick. We'll jump over our special candlestick, just like Jack does in the rhyme. It's super fun to move our bodies while we sing!

slides.prompt: Jump over the candlestick in different ways: two feet, one foot, backward! Then try to recite ALL 10 nursery rhymes.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you are doing so great! Now, let's try jumping in different ways, like maybe on one foot or backward, and sing our rhymes super fast or super slow. After that, we can try to sing all the rhymes we know – you’re becoming a rhyme superstar!

slides.text: 'Ten nursery rhymes in your collection! You're a rhyme expert!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child recite both new rhymes and count along?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay! You learned two new nursery rhymes and practiced jumping! You are a rhyming expert now, and you even counted all the way to ten. That was so much fun, and you did an amazing job!

parent_notes: 'One Two Buckle My Shoe' naturally practices counting by twos and connects numbers to rhyming words — a bridge between math and language. 'Jack Be Nimble' is perfect for burning energy while learning. Adding physical challenges (jump backward, jump on one foot) develops gross motor skills alongside language. These movement rhymes are great for transitions or energy breaks during the school day.

title: Brown Stair — Extensions and Language
description: Brown Stair extension work with vocabulary: thick, thin, thicker, thinner, thickest, thinnest. The child arranges the prisms and uses comparison language.
instructions:
1. Build the Brown Stair.
2. Introduce vocabulary: pick up the thickest prism. 'This is THICK.' Pick up the thinnest. 'This is THIN.'
3. Compare two prisms: 'This one is THICKER. This one is THINNER.'
4. Superlatives: 'This is the THICKEST of all. This is the THINNEST of all.'
5. Three-period lesson for thick/thin vocabulary.
6. Extension: build the stair with eyes closed, using only touch!

slides.heading: Brown Stair
slides.mascot_explanation: Look, friend! Today we're going to play with something called the Brown Stair, and we're going to learn some new words about how things feel. It's going to be so much fun using our hands and our words!

slides.setup_instructions: Build the stair on the mat first. Then use it for language and extensions.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these special blocks! These are called prisms, and they are all different sizes. We also have a soft mat to put them on, and maybe even a special blindfold for a surprise later! Can you help your grown-up find these things so we can start our game?

slides.text: Build the stair. Hold up the thickest prism: 'This is THICK.' Hold the thinnest: 'This is THIN.'
slides.mascot_explanation: First, we need to build our Brown Stair! Let's stack these blocks from thick to thin, like a little staircase. Then, we'll pick up the very biggest, fattest block and say "This is THICK!" And then we'll find the skinniest, smallest one and say "This is THIN!"

slides.text: Compare two: 'This one is THICKER than this one. This one is THINNER.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's pick up two blocks. See how this one is a little bit bigger than this one? We can say, "This one is THICKER," and "This one is THINNER." We're comparing them to see how they are different!

slides.text: Three-period lesson: 'Show me thick. Show me thin. Which one is thicker?' 'What is this — thick or thin?'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is like a fun game of "I Spy" with our blocks! Your grown-up will ask you to "Show me thin," and you'll find the skinny block. Then they might ask, "Which one is thicker?" and you'll point to the fatter one. We're practicing our new words!

slides.text: Eyes-closed extension: mix up 3 prisms. Can you order them thick to thin just by feeling?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for a super exciting challenge! We'll close our eyes, or maybe use that blindfold. We'll mix up just three blocks and try to put them in order from thick to thin just by feeling them with our fingers. Can your hands feel the difference?

slides.prompt: Build the Brown Stair, then try the blindfold challenge with 3 prisms! Can you feel which is thicker?
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's play! We'll build our stair, and then try that fun game with our eyes closed and just our hands. Can you feel which block is thicker and which one is thinner? It's like a secret code only your hands can read!

slides.text: 'Thick, thicker, thickest. Thin, thinner, thinnest. Your hands and eyes both know the difference!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child use thick/thin vocabulary correctly and order by touch?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job today! You learned how to say "thick," "thin," "thicker," and "thinner," and you even used your super-smart fingers to feel the difference without even looking! High five, friend!

parent_notes: Adding precise vocabulary to sensorial materials is a key Montessori practice. The child first experiences the concept (through the material), then receives the language (vocabulary). This order — experience before language — means the words have deep meaning. The blindfold extension isolates the tactile sense, making discrimination even more precise.

title: Metal Insets — Quatrefoil and Combining Shapes
description: Metal inset work with the quatrefoil shape and creating designs by combining multiple inset shapes on one paper.
instructions:
1. Present the quatrefoil metal inset (four overlapping circles).
2. Trace and fill as usual.
3. Then: take two different insets (e.g., circle and triangle) and overlap them on the same paper.
4. Trace both. The overlapping area creates a new shape!
5. Fill different sections with different colors.
6. This creates beautiful geometric art.
materials_needed: Metal insets (quatrefoil plus 2 others of child's choice)

slides.heading: Metal Insets
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun title! We're going to play with special shapes called "metal insets" and make beautiful pictures. It's like drawing with stencils, but super cool!

slides.setup_instructions: Let the child choose which shapes to combine.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we have lots of fun things to use! We have a special flower-like shape called a quatrefoil, and some other shapes too. We also have paper and pretty colored pencils to make our art bright and happy!

slides.text: 'The quatrefoil is a special shape — it has four round petals!' Trace and fill.
slides.mascot_explanation: This special shape is called a quatrefoil, and it looks like a flower with four petals! We're going to carefully trace around it, just like we're drawing its outline. Then, we'll fill it in with color!

slides.text: 'Now let's try something new: put two shapes on the SAME paper!' Place a circle inset, trace. Place a triangle overlapping, trace.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now for something super exciting! We get to put two different shapes on the same paper. Let's put a circle here, trace it, and then put a triangle right on top of it and trace that one too!

slides.text: 'See the area where they overlap? That's a NEW shape! Color each section a different color.'
slides.mascot_explanation: See how the circle and the triangle squish together in the middle? That makes a brand new shape all by itself! We're going to color each part a different color to make our picture super colorful.

slides.prompt: Create 2 overlapping designs using different shape combinations. Use many colors. Which is your favorite?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be the artist! You get to pick two shapes, put them together, trace them, and color them with lots of different colors. Make two amazing pictures and then tell me which one you like the best!

slides.text: Display your designs. 'When shapes overlap, they create new patterns. That's geometry art!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child create a multi-shape overlapping design with different colors?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! Look at all the wonderful art you made by overlapping shapes! You learned that when shapes get together, they can make new shapes and beautiful patterns, just like magic!

parent_notes: Overlapping shapes is a significant extension of metal inset work. It introduces the geometric concept of intersection (where shapes overlap, a new shape is created) in a beautiful, hands-on way. This work is also excellent for decision-making: which shapes? which colors? where to overlap? The results look like stained glass windows and make wonderful gifts.

title: Numeral Writing on Paper — 6 through 10
description: Continuing numeral writing on paper with numerals 6-10. The child completes the full set of single-digit numeral formation.
instructions:
1. Review sandpaper numerals 6-10: trace each one.
2. Write each in the sand tray.
3. Transition to paper: demonstrate 6, 7, 8, 9, 10.
4. Special attention: 10 is TWO digits! '1 and 0 together make ten.'
5. Child writes a row of each: 6, 7, 8, 9, 10.
6. Review: write all numerals 0-10 in order.

slides.heading: Numeral Writing
slides.mascot_explanation: Look, we're going to learn how to write some new numbers today! We'll practice writing numbers on paper, and these are the special numbers from six all the way to ten.

slides.setup_instructions: Warm up with sandpaper and sand. Then transition to paper.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here are the fun things we need for our number adventure! We have bumpy numbers that feel like sand, a special tray with sand to draw in, paper with lines to keep our numbers straight, and a pencil to do our writing. Ask your grown-up to help you find them all!

slides.text: Warm up: trace sandpaper numerals 6-10. Write each in the sand tray.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's get our fingers ready for writing! First, we'll trace the bumpy numbers with our fingers, feeling how they are made. Then, we'll take our finger and draw each number in the soft sand, just like we're making magic shapes!

slides.text: Paper: demonstrate 6 (curve down and around). '6 curls like a snail!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're going to write the number six on paper! Watch me carefully, I make a little curve that goes down and around, just like a snail's shell. It's a fun shape to make!

slides.text: Continue: 7 (across and down), 8 (S curve then close), 9 (like 6 upside down), 10 (a 1 and a 0 together).
slides.mascot_explanation: We're going to keep going with our numbers! We'll make a seven by drawing a line across and then down, an eight looks like a wiggly snake eating its tail, and a nine is like the number six turned upside down.

slides.text: '10 is special — it's our first two-digit number! It takes TWO numerals to write ten.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, ten is a super special number! It's the first number we're writing that uses two little numbers, a one and a zero, standing next to each other to make the big number ten.

slides.prompt: Write a row of each: 6, 7, 8, 9, 10. Then write all numbers from 0 to 10 in order!
slides.mascot_explanation: Time to show off your amazing writing! We're going to write a whole line of sixes, then a line of sevens, and keep going until we write lines of eights, nines, and tens. Then, we'll try writing all the numbers from zero to ten in order, like a super number train!

slides.text: 'You can write every number from zero to ten! That's eleven different numbers!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child write recognizable numerals 0-10?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You can write all the numbers from zero all the way to ten – that's a whole lot of numbers! You are such a super star number writer!

parent_notes: Numerals 6 and 8 are the trickiest to form. 6 is often written backward (looking like a lowercase 'g') and 8 requires a smooth S-curve. Don't worry about perfect formation — it improves with practice over weeks and months. Note that 10 introduces the concept of a two-digit number. This is a BIG idea: we need two symbols because we ran out of single digits after 9.

title: Magnetic or Non-Magnetic — Extension and Magnet Strength
description: Extending the magnet experiment by testing whether magnets work through different materials and exploring magnet strength.
instructions:
1. Review: 'What did we learn about magnets last time?'
2. New question: 'Can a magnet work THROUGH things?'
3. Test: put a paper clip on a piece of paper. Move the magnet under the paper.
4. Try through cardboard, fabric, plastic container, water, thin wood.
5. Test magnet strength: how many paper clips can the magnet hold in a chain?
6. Record results on a simple chart.

slides.heading: Magnets
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! We are going to play with magnets again today! We will learn a super cool new thing about them.

slides.setup_instructions: Gather various materials for the magnet to work through.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's get ready for our magnet adventure! We need our strong magnet, some tiny paper clips, a piece of paper, some cardboard, soft fabric, a little container with water, and a paper to draw on. Ask a grown-up to help you find all these fun things!

slides.text: 'Last time we learned WHAT magnets attract. Today we ask: can magnets work THROUGH things?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Remember how magnets love to stick to some things? Well, today we're going to ask a new question: can a magnet pull things even when there's something in the way? It's like a magnet mystery!

slides.text: Place a paper clip on paper. Move the magnet underneath. 'It moved! The magnet works through paper!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Look, we're going to try something super neat! First, put a little paper clip on top of the paper. Now, slide the magnet underneath the paper, like this. See? The paper clip moved all by itself – the magnet worked right through the paper!

slides.text: Test through cardboard, fabric, a plastic container (put clip inside), thin wood. Record: yes or no.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's try with other things, like cardboard or soft fabric. Can the magnet pull the paper clip through those too? We'll put a paper clip inside the plastic cup and try too! We'll draw a happy face if it works and a sleepy face if it doesn't.

slides.text: Strength test: how many paper clips can chain from the magnet? Count your chain!
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the super fun strength test! Let's see how many paper clips our magnet can hold. We'll stick one paper clip to the magnet, then stick another one to that one, and keep going to make a long, long chain! How many can you make?

slides.prompt: Test all the materials. Record your results. Then build the longest paper clip chain you can!
slides.mascot_explanation: Time to be scientists! Let's try all the things we have to see if the magnet works through them, and draw our happy or sleepy faces. Then, let's make the longest paper clip chain ever, like a magnet train!

slides.text: 'Magnets work through thin materials! The magnet's force can pass through paper, fabric, and even water!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child test and record whether the magnet works through each material?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, we did it! We learned that magnets are so strong, their pulling power can go right through paper, cloth, and even water! You were such a good scientist, testing everything and building that amazing paper clip chain!

parent_notes: This extension deepens the child's understanding of magnetic force. The key discovery is that magnetism passes through non-magnetic materials (paper, fabric, plastic, water) but is blocked by thick or magnetic materials. The paper clip chain measures 'magnet strength' in a child-friendly way. This is real physics! Let the child play freely with magnets after the lesson.

title: Music — Fast and Slow (Tempo)
description: Exploring tempo in music: fast and slow. The child listens to, moves to, and creates music at different speeds.
instructions:
1. Clap a steady beat. 'This is a medium speed.' Clap faster. 'FAST!' Clap slower. 'Slow...'
2. Play or sing a familiar song at regular speed. Then faster. Then slower.
3. Let the child move: walk fast, walk slow. March to the tempo.
4. Use an instrument (drum or shaker): child plays fast when you say fast, slow when you say slow.
5. 'Tempo' means how fast or slow music goes.
6. Listen to two different songs — which is faster?
materials_needed: Music player with two contrasting songs (one fast, one slow)

slides.heading: Music Exploration
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! This is the title for our super fun music adventure today! We're going to play with music that goes fast and music that goes slow. It's going to be so exciting!

slides.setup_instructions: Choose a fast song and a slow song to compare. Clear space for movement.
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, we get to use some fun things for our music game! We have a drum or a shaker, which makes cool sounds when we hit or shake it. We also need a music player, like a tablet or phone, to play our songs. Ask a grown-up to help you find these and get ready for some music fun!

slides.text: 'Music can go FAST — ' (clap quickly) ' — or SLOW — ' (clap slowly). 'This is called TEMPO.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's try clapping our hands! Listen: we can clap like this (clap slowly) — that's slow! And we can clap like this (clap quickly) — that's fast! This is how fast or slow the music goes, and it's called TEMPO. Isn't that a cool word?

slides.text: Sing 'Twinkle Twinkle' at regular speed. Then super fast! Then very slow. 'Which sounds best?'
slides.mascot_explanation: We know that song, "Twinkle, Twinkle Little Star"! Let's sing it together at our normal speed first. Now, let's try singing it super-duper fast! Whoa! And now, let's try singing it really, really slow. Which way did you like singing it best?

slides.text: 'Let's move to the tempo! When I play fast, move fast. When I play slow, move slow.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Get your wiggles ready! We're going to move our bodies to the music's speed. When the music plays fast, we'll move fast! When the music plays slow, we'll move slow. Let's see how good we are at matching the music!

slides.prompt: Play the drum at different tempos. Can you switch from fast to slow and back? Move your body to match!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to play the drum or shaker! Let's try playing it fast, like a race car! Vroom vroom! Now, let's try playing it super slow, like a sleepy turtle. Can you switch between fast and slow? Let’s also move our bodies to the music’s speed!

slides.text: 'We've learned loud/soft, high/low, and now fast/slow. These are the building blocks of music!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify and produce fast versus slow tempos?
slides.mascot_explanation: We did it! We learned all about fast and slow music, which is called tempo! We clapped fast and slow, moved our bodies fast and slow, and even played our instruments fast and slow. You are a super music explorer!

parent_notes: We've now covered three fundamental music concepts: dynamics (loud/soft), pitch (high/low), and tempo (fast/slow). Movement is the best way for young children to internalize tempo — they feel the speed in their bodies. Classical music offers wonderful examples: compare a waltz (slow, graceful) with a march (fast, energetic). Dancing to music is learning!

title: Sewing — Running Stitch on Burlap
description: First sewing project: the running stitch on burlap or loose-weave fabric. The child sews in and out along a drawn line.
instructions:
1. Thread the needle (review from day 3).
2. Draw a straight line on burlap with a marker.
3. Demonstrate: push needle up through the fabric, pull through, push down through the fabric.
4. 'Up, down, up, down — like a dolphin swimming!'
5. Follow the line. Stitches should be roughly even.
6. Tie off at the end. Admire the work!
materials_needed: Burlap or loose-weave fabric (6x6 inch piece)

slides.heading: Sewing
slides.mascot_explanation: Look! We're going to learn how to sew today, like how grown-ups make clothes! It's going to be super fun.

slides.setup_instructions: Thread the needle. Draw a straight line across the burlap. Optional: secure burlap in hoop.
slides.mascot_explanation: These are the special things we need for our sewing adventure! We have a piece of burlap, which is like a bumpy cloth, and a needle with some colorful yarn already threaded through it. We also have a marker to draw a line, and maybe a hoop to hold our cloth. Ask your grown-up to help you find everything!

slides.text: Thread the needle together (review). Draw a straight line on the burlap.
slides.mascot_explanation: First, let's get our burlap ready for sewing. We need to draw a nice, straight line on it with the marker, just like we're drawing a road for our needle to follow.

slides.text: 'We're going to sew along this line. Watch: push the needle UP from underneath.' Pull through.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, watch me! We're going to push the needle up from the back of the cloth, right on our line. See? We pull the yarn all the way through.

slides.text: 'Now push it DOWN a little bit ahead.' Pull through underneath. 'UP again!' Continue along the line.
slides.mascot_explanation: Next, we take the needle and push it down into the cloth just a little bit ahead of where it came out. Then we pull it through again from the back. We'll keep doing this, going up and down, up and down.

slides.text: 'Up, down, up, down — like a dolphin jumping in and out of the water!'
slides.mascot_explanation: See how we go up and then down? It looks like a little dolphin jumping out of the water and then diving back in! Up, down, up, down, just like that!

slides.prompt: Sew along the entire line with the running stitch. Try to keep your stitches roughly the same size.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to try! We're going to follow that line we drew, going up and down, up and down, making our stitches. Try to make them all about the same size, like little footsteps. You can do it!

slides.text: 'You SEWED! That line of stitches is called a running stitch. People have been sewing for thousands of years.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child complete a line of running stitches along the drawn path?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You made a whole line of stitches, and we call that a running stitch! You are a super sewer, just like people have been for a very, very long time. You made something special today!

parent_notes: Burlap is ideal for first sewing because the loose weave makes it easy to push the needle through. An embroidery hoop holds the fabric taut, making sewing easier. Don't worry about stitch size consistency — that comes with practice. Sewing develops patience, fine motor skills, hand-eye coordination, and a sense of accomplishment. Many children become absorbed in sewing work.

title: Oral Language — Retelling a Story
description: The child practices retelling a familiar story in their own words. Building narrative skills, sequencing, and oral fluency.
instructions:
1. Choose a story the child knows well (from recent read-alouds).
2. 'Can you tell me the story of Corduroy? What happened first?'
3. Help with sequence prompts: 'And then what happened? What came next?'
4. Encourage details: 'What did the store look like? How did Corduroy feel?'
5. If the child gets stuck, offer a choice: 'Did he go upstairs or outside?'
6. Celebrate the retelling! 'You told that whole story yourself!'
materials_needed: A familiar picture book for reference

slides.heading: Oral Language
slides.mascot_explanation: Hi friend! We're going to play a game today about telling stories. It's going to be super fun, and you're going to be amazing at it!

slides.setup_instructions: Choose a book the child has heard at least twice. Have it nearby but closed.
slides.mascot_explanation: Look, we need a special book for our game today. It's a book you already know and love, maybe one we read lots of times! We'll keep it close, but don't open it yet.

slides.text: 'You know the story of Corduroy so well. Can you TELL it to me? Pretend I've never heard it!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, now it's your turn to be the storyteller! Remember that fun book, Corduroy? I want you to tell me all about it, like I've never heard it before.

slides.text: Prompt: 'How does the story start? Where is Corduroy?' Let the child narrate.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's start at the very beginning! Can you tell me how the story begins? What was Corduroy doing when we first met him?

slides.text: Guide with questions: 'What happened next? Then what? And at the end?'
slides.mascot_explanation: After that, what happened in the story? Keep telling me everything that happened next, step by step. We'll go through the whole story together!

slides.text: Encourage details: 'What did Corduroy look like? How did Lisa feel?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you're doing so great telling the story! Can you tell me more? What did Corduroy look like? How did the little girl feel when she saw him?

slides.prompt: Retell the whole story from beginning to end. Use the pictures in the book if you need help remembering.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to tell the whole story from the very start to the very end. You can look at the pictures in the book if you need a little reminder, but I know you remember it all!

slides.text: 'You told that whole story! You remembered the beginning, middle, and end. You're a storyteller!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child retell a familiar story with a clear beginning, middle, and end?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You told the whole story all by yourself, from the beginning to the middle to the end! You are such a wonderful storyteller, I'm so proud of you!

parent_notes: Story retelling is one of the strongest predictors of reading comprehension. The child must remember events, sequence them logically, and express them in their own words — complex cognitive work! Don't interrupt to correct; let the child's version flow. You can gently add details after: 'You told it so well! I also remember that...' Make retelling a regular activity after every read-aloud.

title: Memory Game — Quantities with Challenge Numbers
description: The Memory Game with higher numbers and multiple rounds. Building mental number sense and working memory for larger quantities.
instructions:
1. Set up the Memory Game as in week 5.
2. This time, include numeral cards for 7, 8, 9, and 10 more frequently.
3. Play 5 rounds with challenging numbers.
4. Extension: draw TWO cards and add them. 'You drew 3 and 4. How many total? Bring back 7!'
5. Another extension: 'Bring me 6 red beads and 4 blue beads.'
6. Verify each time by counting together.
materials_needed: Numeral cards 1-10 (with extras of high numbers)

slides.heading: Memory Game
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look! It's our super fun Memory Game, but this time it's a *challenge* round! That means we get to play with even bigger numbers and be super thinkers!
