slides.setup_instructions: Place objects across the room. Include extra cards for 7, 8, 9, 10.
slides.mascot_explanation: We need some special things to play our game! We have number cards with big numbers like 7, 8, 9, and 10, and we also have colorful little toys. We'll also use baskets and mats to help us keep everything neat. Ask a grown-up to help you get all these things ready!

slides.text: 'The Memory Game is back — with a CHALLENGE! This time, the numbers might be bigger.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Guess what? Our favorite Memory Game is back, and it's a big challenge this time! We're going to play with even bigger numbers than before, so we need to use our super memory muscles!

slides.text: Draw a card: '9! That's a big number. Remember it. Walk over. Count out 9. Bring them back!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's try drawing a card! Oh, look, it's a 9! That's a big number, so remember it in your head. Now, walk over to where the toys are and count out 9 of them, then bring them back to our mat. You can do it!

slides.text: Extension: draw two cards. '3 and 5. How many is that together? Walk over and bring back 8!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to do something extra tricky! We'll draw two number cards, like maybe a 3 and a 5. Can you try to remember them both and think about how many that is together? Then, we'll go count out that total number!

slides.text: Color challenge: 'Bring me 4 red and 3 blue.' Child must remember BOTH the quantity AND the color.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is a color challenge! We need to remember two things: how many and what color. Can you bring me 4 red toys *and* 3 blue toys? That means you have to remember both numbers and their colors!

slides.prompt: Play 5 challenge rounds. Try the two-card addition version! Can you add and remember?
slides.mascot_explanation: We're going to play five rounds of this super challenge game, and we can even try adding two numbers together from memory! It's like being a math detective, finding out how many things we need all at once!

slides.text: 'Your number memory is getting stronger! You can hold big numbers in your head!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child accurately gather quantities up to 10 and attempt simple addition from memory?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, you did it! Your brain is amazing at remembering all those big numbers and colors! You are getting so good at counting and remembering, and that's super important for being a great learner!

parent_notes: The two-card extension turns the Memory Game into an addition game — the child must add mentally AND hold the sum in working memory while walking and counting. This is challenging! If the child struggles with the addition extension, stick with single cards until they're ready. The two-color version adds another layer of complexity that develops working memory.

title: Celebrations Around the World — Diwali
description: Learning about Diwali, the Festival of Lights celebrated primarily in India. Exploring how different cultures celebrate with light, food, and togetherness.
instructions:
1. Find India on the globe (Asia, yellow continent).
2. 'In India and many other countries, people celebrate DIWALI — the Festival of Lights!'
3. Show pictures of Diwali: oil lamps (diyas), rangoli patterns, fireworks, special foods.
4. Explain: 'Diwali celebrates the victory of light over darkness and good over bad.'
5. Make a simple rangoli pattern with colored rice or chalk.
6. Light a small candle together (supervised) to celebrate light.
materials_needed: Small candle and matches (for adult use)

slides.heading: Celebrations
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! We're going to learn all about special parties, and one is called Diwali. It's a super fun "Festival of Lights" that people celebrate!

slides.setup_instructions: Print or display Diwali images. Prepare colored rice in small bowls.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's get ready for our Diwali fun! We need a globe to find a country, some pretty pictures, colorful rice or chalk to draw with, paper, and a little candle to make light. Ask a grown-up to help you find these things!

slides.text: Find India on the globe. 'India is in ASIA — the yellow continent. It's one of the biggest countries in the world!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's go on an adventure to find India on our globe! See that big yellow part? That's Asia, and inside it is India, where people have a special festival. Can you point to it?

slides.text: 'People in India celebrate DIWALI — the Festival of Lights! They light thousands of small lamps called diyas.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Guess what? People in India have a big party called Diwali, which means "Festival of Lights"! They light up their homes with lots and lots of little lamps, like tiny, happy stars.

slides.text: Show pictures: diyas, rangoli patterns on floors, fireworks, sweets. 'Diwali celebrates light winning over darkness.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at these amazing pictures! We see the little lamps, pretty patterns on the floor, bright fireworks, and yummy treats! Diwali is all about how the good light always wins, like when the sun comes out after it gets dark.

slides.prompt: Make a rangoli! Draw a simple symmetrical pattern on paper or the ground. Fill it with colored rice or chalk. Light a candle to celebrate light!
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to make our own beautiful Diwali art! We'll draw a pattern and fill it with colorful rice or chalk, just like they do. Then, we'll light a tiny candle together to celebrate the light and goodness.

slides.text: 'Diwali reminds us that light and goodness always win. People all around the world celebrate in special ways.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain what Diwali celebrates and locate India on the globe?
slides.mascot_explanation: We learned that Diwali is a special "Festival of Lights" where people celebrate good winning over darkness, and we even found India on the globe! Isn't it cool how people all over the world have such wonderful ways to celebrate?

parent_notes: Learning about celebrations from around the world builds respect for cultural diversity. Diwali is one of the world's most widely celebrated festivals. Keep the explanation age-appropriate: light over darkness, good over bad. Making rangoli (colorful floor patterns) is a wonderful hands-on cultural activity. If you have neighbors who celebrate Diwali, this is a beautiful opportunity for connection.

title: Read-Aloud: Strega Nona
description: Reading Tomie dePaola's Italian folktale about Big Anthony and a magic pasta pot. Exploring themes of responsibility, consequences, and different cultures.
instructions:
1. Show the cover. 'Strega Nona means Grandma Witch in Italian. She has a magic pasta pot!'
2. Read with expression. Use a special voice for Strega Nona.
3. Build suspense when Big Anthony uses the pot alone.
4. 'Uh oh! The pasta won't stop! What should he do?'
5. After reading: 'What lesson did Big Anthony learn?'
6. Discuss: 'Have you ever done something you were told not to? What happened?'

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! This is the special book we get to read today. It's called "Strega Nona," and it's a fun story from a country called Italy.

slides.setup_instructions: Sit comfortably together.
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, it's time for our story! We need our special book to read. Can you help me find it? Maybe ask a grown-up to get it for us so we can snuggle up and start our adventure!

slides.text: Cover: 'This story comes from ITALY. Strega Nona has a MAGIC pasta pot. But what happens when someone else uses it?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at the cover of our book! "Strega Nona" is a special name from Italy, and it means "Grandma Witch." She has a super-duper magic pot that makes pasta, but oh no, what do you think happens when someone else tries to use it?

slides.text: Read with character voices. Build suspense as pasta overflows!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to read the story! I'm going to use funny voices for the characters, and we'll pretend to be very excited and a little bit scared when the pasta starts to go everywhere. Let's see if we can guess what will happen next!

slides.text: After: 'Why couldn't Big Anthony stop the pot? What did Strega Nona know that he didn't?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Oh dear, the pasta just won't stop coming out of the pot! Why do you think Big Anthony couldn't stop it? What did Strega Nona know about her magic pot that he didn't know?

slides.prompt: 'What lesson did Big Anthony learn? Have you ever been told not to do something but did it anyway? What happened?'
slides.mascot_explanation: That was a funny story, wasn't it? Big Anthony learned a big lesson about listening. Have you ever done something that someone told you not to do? What happened when you did it?

slides.text: 'When we don't listen to instructions, things can go wrong — even with magic! That's a lesson from Italy.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain the cause and effect in the story?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we learned so much today from our story from Italy! We learned that sometimes when we don't listen, things can get a little messy, even with magic! You did such a great job listening and thinking about the story.

parent_notes: This Caldecott Honor book teaches about consequences in a humorous, non-threatening way. Children love the escalating disaster of overflowing pasta. The Italian setting connects to geography (find Italy on the globe!). Big Anthony's punishment (eating all the pasta) feels fair to children's sense of justice. Folktales from different cultures are a cornerstone of Montessori cultural studies.
